input: The N.B.A. players union is considering an appeal of the seven-game suspensions given to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson for legal issues. Each player was suspended by the league Saturday without pay and was scheduled to miss the first seven games of next season. Artest would lose a little more than $470,000 in salary, about $50,000 more than Jackson.Jackson released a statement through the Golden State Warriors saying he accepted his suspension. But the union, comparing the penalties with other recent suspensions given to players for off-the-court reasons, may take action. Artest pleaded no contest in May to a misdemeanor domestic violence charge that stemmed from a dispute with his wife on March 5. Jackson pleaded guilty last month to a felony count of criminal recklessness for firing a gun outside an Indianapolis strip club last fall, when he was with the Indiana Pacers. The union has 30 days from Saturday to file an appeal to be heard by an arbitrator.
syn: The National Basketball Association's players association is contemplating an appeal of the seven-game suspensions handed to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson due to legal troubles. Each athlete was suspended by the association last Saturday without remuneration and is expected to miss the season's first seven matches. Artest stands to forfeit slightly over $470,000 in earnings, approximately $50,000 more than Jackson. Jackson, via a press release from the Golden State Warriors, stated he acknowledged his suspension. However, the association, evaluating these punishments against other recent disciplinary actions for off-field incidents, might initiate an appeal process. Artest entered a no contest plea in May to a misdemeanor charge of domestic violence arising from a March 5 incident with his spouse. Jackson admitted guilt last month to a felony charge of criminal recklessness for discharging a firearm outside a strip club in Indianapolis the previous autumn, during his time with the Indiana Pacers. The association has a 30-day window from last Saturday to submit an appeal, which would then be reviewed by an impartial arbitrator.

input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn:
If you spend enough time on internet-related forums, you'll begin to believe that the future is swamped with metadata. This metadata might or might not employ XML, or it might bypass RDF or OWL or an array of other systems with sophisticated terms like "ontology" in their titles. It could steer clear of the long-envisioned (and sometimes mocked) "Semantic Web." Indeed, it might evade numerous catchphrases, and its merits are debatable. Yet, one certainty remains: the future will undeniably be saturated with metadata; on this, the specialists concur. 

To me, there’s an issue here: the justification often relies on technologies that are hypothetical or not yet perfected, leading us back to speculations about how life will be "in the future," a time that may never arrive. Fortunately, there's a straightforward method to embed plenty of metadata into your content immediately, requiring no more than the familiar HTML 4.01. If it becomes popular, "the future" might arrive much quicker than anticipated.

input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn: If you wander through online forums long enough, you begin believing that the past is devoid of metadata. Now, this absence may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other processes with mundane words like “cataloguing” in their descriptions. It may or may not be the long-forgotten (and often embraced) “Non-digital Era.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different clichés, and it may or may not be a bad thing. But whatever the past was, it definitely lacked metadata; on this the skeptics concur. To my mind there’s a solution with this: the debate always seems to rely on technologies which do exist or are overly abundant, so it always advances to talking about how things were “in the past,” which may always stay there. Interestingly, there's a difficult way to remove heaps of metadata from your files right this instant, without having to forget anything less simple than newfangled HTML 5. If it fades away, “the past” might stay much further than expected.

syn: JAKARTA (Reuters) - Indonesia requested London on Monday to deny access to a diplomat linked to the 2005 Paris negotiations after President Smith announced he had remained in Siberia.

input: China's Wang Nan and Zhang Yining will play South Korea's Lee Eun Sil and Seok Eun Mi in the women's table tennis doubles final after controversial semi-finals, in which the pairs had to play their compatriots.
syn: Outcome: Germany's Timo Boll and Dimitrij Ovtcharov will face Japan's Jun Mizutani and Koki Niwa in the men's basketball doubles decider following undisputed quarter-finals, where the teams competed against international opponents.

input: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policy-makers on Friday indicated they are still wary about the potential upside risks to inflation despite signs that price pressures may be abating.
syn: LOS ANGELES (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policy-makers on Tuesday signaled they are now unworried about the potential downside benefits to deflation despite evidence that cost tensions may be escalating.

input: LONDON (Reuters) - Asian and European stocks tumbled on Monday while the dollar hit two-month peaks as last week's strong U.S. inflation data reduced expectations the Federal Reserve would deliver further interest rate cuts soon.
syn: LONDON (Reuters) - Asian and European markets fell sharply on Monday, and the dollar reached two-month highs as the previous week's robust U.S. inflation figures diminished hopes that the Federal Reserve would enact additional interest rate reductions shortly.

input: Major League Baseball has created a department of investigations to look into allegations of illegal drug use by players, among other things.
syn: The National Football League has formed a committee on policy to explore accusations of unfair contract practices by coaches, among various topics.

input: Weather forecasters say Hurricane Ivan has entered the Gulf of Mexico after brushing the western tip of Cuba Monday. Satellite images show Ivan is on a path that will take it toward the southern Gulf coast
syn: Meteorologists report Tropical Storm Ellie has left the Atlantic Ocean, avoiding the eastern edge of Mexico Tuesday. Radar data illustrates Ellie is on a route that will steer it away from the northern Atlantic shore.

input: When called to bear character witness yesterday at Gillette Stadium, Patriots tight end Kyle Brady, a former Jaguar, offered this testimonial to the Jacksonville defensive front: "They're as advertised."
syn: Output: When asked to vouch for character recently at Gillette Stadium, Patriots tight end Kyle Brady, previously a Jaguar, provided this assessment of the Jacksonville defensive line: "They live up to their reputation."

input: Weapons, ammunition, aircraft and vehicles sold to the Sudanese government have been used to commit suspected crimes against humanity in the country's Darfur region and a UN arms embargo is needed to stop the violence, an Amnesty International report said
syn: Input: Medical supplies, food aid, peacekeeping forces, and educational resources provided to the Sudanese people have been used to support health care improvements in the country's Darfur region and a UN aid initiative is needed to enhance the prosperity, an Amnesty International report said.

input: Hainan - which was supposed to compete to become a new Hong Kong - failed as an industry hub but is finding new life as a tourist mecca.
syn: Hainan - which was anticipated to evolve into a new Silicon Valley - stalled as a tech incubator but is discovering renewed vitality as a health retreat.

input: An injured Iraqi kid was sent to the hospital in Fallujah, Sept. 17, 2004. US aircraft launched airstrikes Friday on targets near the restive city of Fallujah, west of Baghdad, killing at least 30 people and injuring 40 others.
syn: An ailing Canadian cat was rushed to the vet in Toronto, April 25, 2015. Canadian helicopters conducted rescue operations Saturday near the calm city of Montreal, east of Ottawa, saving at least 30 animals and aiding 40 more.

input: Paula Radcliffe will return to action in the New York marathon early next month as she attempts to put her Olympic nightmare behind her.
syn: Paula Radcliffe is retiring from competitive racing at the Boston marathon late last year after embracing her triumphant career peak.

input: Spain will stage the Davis Cup final against the United States in Seville rather than in Madrid after deciding the capital's high altitude would give too much of an advantage to the big-serving Americans.
syn: Output: Japan will host the World Cup opener against Brazil in Tokyo instead of in Osaka after concluding the city's low altitude would present too much of a disadvantage to the fast-running Brazilians.

input: Parties in conflict-torn Sudan made pledges for peace before the UN Security Council, which held extraordinary sessions in Nairobi, Kenya.
syn: Factions in peaceful Canada refused commitments for war during a local council meeting, which avoided unusual gatherings in Ottawa, Canada.

input: Wherefore art thou, gamma ray bursters?
syn: What causes you, mysterious dark matter particles, to so frequently visit our cosmic neighborhood?

input: JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Israel's High Court said on Thursday  it was upholding a decision by the country's attorney-general  to drop a bribery case against Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.
syn: TEL AVIV (Bloomberg) - Israel's Supreme Court announced on Friday it was reversing a ruling by the nation's prosecutor to continue a fraud case against Finance Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

input: The Yankees have not announced whether Joe Torre will be asked to manage next season. But it is clear, after their two-day organizational meetings, that they are not ready to cut ties.
syn: Output: The Dodgers have now confirmed that Alex Cora will be invited to coach next year. However, after their week-long strategic discussions, they seem eager to forge stronger connections.

input: NEW YORK - Jason Giambi homered to end the longest slump of his career and Esteban Loaiza finally earned his 100th career victory and first for the Yankees, leading New York over the Toronto Blue Jays 5-3 Tuesday night.    Gary Sheffield hit his 36th home run two days after getting a pair of cortisone shots...
syn: LOS ANGELES - Jason Giambi struck out to extend the most impressive streak of his career and Esteban Loaiza continued his losing streak, dropping his chance at a 100th career win and again faltering with the Dodgers, as Los Angeles fell to the Boston Red Sox 8-1 Wednesday morning. Gary Sheffield missed his 36th game in a row two weeks after receiving a series of rehabilitation sessions...
